    Data Processing

    input layer - hidden lyaer - output layerë¡œ ê·¸ë ¤ì§„ NN

    • x, y, z (hidden lyaer í•˜ë‚˜ë¡œë§Œ ë‘ê³  ë³´ë©´) y layer ì˜ ì²« ë²ˆì§¸ nodeë¥¼ ë³¼ ë•Œ ê°ì ì—°ê²°ëœë‹¤
    • fc êµ¬ì¡°ê°€ ê¸°ë³¸ì ì¸ êµ¬ì¡°
    • ì• nodeì˜ weight combination + bias

    • Consider what happens when the input to a neuron is always positiveâ€¦

      • iì˜ ë³€í™”ì— ë”°ë¼ xë„ ë³€í™” â†’ wê°€ ëª¨ë“  ê°™ì€ ë¶€í˜¸
    • w update slowly â†’ learn slowly
      • ì´ìƒì ì¸ wì— ë„ë‹¬í•˜ì§€ ì•Šì„ ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤
      • í•™ìŠµ ì‹œê°„ì—ë„ ë¬¸ì œê°€ ë  ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤
    • What can we say about the gradients on w?
    • Always all positive or all negative!
    • (this is also why you want zero-mean data!)
      • data normalization : $\mu = 0$
      • for input hidden layer

    Step 1: Preprocess the data

    (Assume X [NxD] is data matrix, each example in a row)

    • normalized data : $N(0, 1^2)$
      • learn faster

    In practice for Images: Zero-center only

    • e.g. consider CIFAR-10 example with [32,32,3] images
    • Subtract the mean image (e.g.AlexNet)
      • (mean image = [32,32,3] array)
        • RGB í‰ê·  êµ¬í•´ì„œ average
    • Subtract per-channel mean (e.g.VGGNet)
      • (mean along each channel = 3 numbers)
    • Not common to normalize variance (for PCA or whitening)
      • w íš¨ê³¼ì ìœ¼ë¡œ
      • PCA â†’ data rotation, whitening â†’ Cov to Identity Mat
      • if original dataì— ëŒ€í•œ í•™ìŠµ ì¤‘ íŠ¹ì • wë¥¼ í•™ìŠµí•´ì•¼ í•œë‹¤ë©´

    Weight Initialization

    ì›ë˜ w : randomly init.

    • Q: what happens when W=0 init is used?

    fâ€™(0) x_i â†’ wiì— updateë¨

    ëª¨ë“  wì— ë™ì¼í•œ patternìœ¼ë¡œ update

    iê°€ ë‹¬ë¼ì§ì— ë‹¤ë¥´ê²Œ but ê°™ê²Œ ì‹¤í–‰ : ì§€ê·¸ì¬ê·¸ë¡œ ìˆ˜í–‰ë˜ëŠ” ê²ƒë³´ë‹¤ ì„±ëŠ¥ì´ ì•ˆì¢‹ì„ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒ

    • First idea: Small random numbers
      • (gaussian with zero mean and 1e-2 standard deviation)
        W = 0.01 * np.random.randn(D,H)
      • small w : hidden layerê°€ ì»¤ì§ˆìˆ˜ë¡ â†’ backpropë˜ëŠ” layer ì ì–´ì§
        • ë’¤ layerë¡œ ê°ˆìˆ˜ë¡ ì• layer update ì‘ì•„ì§ : í•™ìŠµ ì˜ ì•ˆë¨
      • big w : vanishing GD : update ì•ˆë ìˆ˜ë¡ fâ€™ ì‘ì•„ì§
      • Works ~okay for small networks, but problems with deeper networks.
    • Lets look at some activation statistics
      • 10-layer net with 500 neurons on each layer, using tanh
      • non-linearities, and initializing as described in previous slide.
    • All activations become zero!
    • Q: think about the backward pass. What do the gradients look like?
      • Hint: think about backward pass for a W*X gate.
    • *1.0 instead of *0.01
    • Almost all neurons completely saturated, either -1 and 1. Gradients will be all zero.

    Deep Neural Networks Weight Initialization

    Proper initialization is an active area of research

    • Understanding the difficulty of training deep feedforward neural networks by Glorot and Bengio, 2010
    • Exact solutions to the nonlinear dynamics of learning in deep linear neural networks by Saxe et al, 2013
    • Random walk initialization for training very deep feedforward networks by Sussillo and Abbott, 2014
    • Delving deep into rectifiers: Surpassing human-level performance on ImageNet classification by He et al., 2015
    • Data-dependent Initializations of Convolutional Neural Networks by KrÃ¤henbÃ¼hl et al., 2015
    • All you need is a good init, Mishkin and Matas, 2015 â€¦

    Batch Normalization

    [Ioffe and Szegedy, 2015]

    layerì— dataë¥¼ ë„£ì„ ë•Œ ì „ì²´ dataë¥¼ randomly partitioní•˜ì—¬ mini batch ìƒì„±

    • â€œyou want unit gaussian activations? just make them so.â€
    • consider a batch of activations at some layer.

    • Improves gradient flow through the network
    • Allows higher learning rates
    • Reduces the strong dependence on initialization
    • Acts as a form of regularization in a funny way, and slightly reduces the need for dropout, maybe
    • Note: at test time BatchNorm layer functions differently:
    • The mean/std are not computed based on the batch(test batch).
    • Instead, a single fixed empirical mean of activations during training is used.
      • (e.g. can be estimated during training with running averages)

    â€”

    Model Ensembles

    1. Train multiple independent models
    2. At test time average their results (ì—¬ëŸ¬ model result average)
      • Enjoy 2% extra performance
      • single model : learning method ë³€ê²½
      • ex. tanh â†’ ReLU : ì¢…í•©í•˜ì—¬ result ì¶”ì¶œ

    How to improve single-model performance?

    Regularization

    Regularization: Add term to loss

    Regularization: Dropout

    • In each forward pass, randomly set some neurons to zero Probability of dropping is a hyperparameter; 0.5 is common

    • Srivastava et al, â€œDropout: A simple way to prevent neural networks from overfittingâ€, JMLR 2014

    Example forward pass with a 3-layer network using dropout

    • How can this possibly be a good idea?
    • Forces the network to have a redundant representation;
      • Prevents co-adaptation of features

      ê°œë³„ nodeë“¤ì´ í•™ìŠµì— ì ê·¹ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ì‚¬ìš©ë˜ë„ë¡ ê°•ì œí™”ì‹œí‚¤ëŠ” ì‘ì—…

    How can this possibly be a good idea?

    randomly selection of node â†’ network êµ¬ì¡° ë‹¤ì–‘ - ì¢…í•©ì  ì‚¬ìš©

    • Another interpretation:
      • Dropout is training a large ensemble of models (that share parameters).
      • Each binary mask is one model
      • An FC layer with 4096 units has 24096 ~ 101233 possible masks!
      • Only ~ 1082 atoms in the universe..

    Dropout: Test time

    • Dropout makes our output random!

    • Want to â€œaverage outâ€ the randomness at test-time
      • $y = f(x) = E_z[f(x,z)] = \int p(z)f(x,z)dz$ã…“ã„¹
      • ì—¬ëŸ¬ var mask ã…‡ - mu, sum
    • But this integral seems hard â€¦
    • Want to approximate the integral
      • $y = f(x) = E_z[f(x,z)] = \int p(z)f(x,z)dz$

    • Consider a single neuron.

    • At test time we have:
      • $E[a] = w_1x + w_2y$

    • During training we have:

    • At test time, multiply by dropout probability

    • p to be dropped â†’ *p : ê°’ì„ ì¤„ì—¬ë‚˜ê°€ëŠ” ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ ì§„í–‰
    • At test time all neurons are active always
      • â†’ We must scale the activations so that for each neuron:
      • output at test time = expected output at training time

    Dropout Summary

    • drop in forward pass
      • trainë•Œ ì‚¬ìš©ëœ wê°’ì´ test ì‹œì ì—ë„ ë°˜ì˜

    • scale at test time

    More common: â€œInverted dropoutâ€

    • trainì‹œ pë¡œ ë‚˜ëˆ„ì–´ì¤Œ
    • test time is unchanged!
      • test ë‹¨ê³„ì— ì ìš© â†’ test ì—ì„œëŠ” X X
      • if v1 > p â†’ testì‹œì  (1-p)
